title: Charles Edward Beckett
text:
Charles Edward Beckett (1849–1925) was a <a href="brigadier-general">brigadier-general</a> and <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> officer in the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a>.
He served in three regiments the <a href="7th%20%28The%20Princess%20Royal%27s%29%20Dragoon%20Guards">7th (The Princess Royal's) Dragoon Guards</a>, the <a href="3rd%20%28The%20King%27s%20Own%29%20Hussars">3rd (The King's Own) Hussars</a> and the <a href="2nd%20Dragoon%20Guards%20%28Queen%27s%20Bays%29">2nd Dragoon Guards (Queen's Bays)</a>, which he also commanded.
He served in three wars, in the <a href="Sudan%20Campaign">Sudan Campaign</a>, the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a> and the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>. During which although only ranked as a brigadier-general he was the first <a href="General%20Officer%20Commanding">General Officer Commanding</a> the <a href="66th%20%282nd%20East%20Lancashire%29%20Division">66th (2nd East Lancashire) Division</a>.
History.
Family life.
Charles Edward Beckett was the son of Charles William Beckett of <a href="Thorne%2C%20South%20Yorkshire">Thorne</a> in <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a>, England. He married Louisa Michel, daughter of <a href="Field-Marshal">Field-Marshal</a> Sir <a href="John%20Michel">John Michel</a> of <a href="Dewlish">Dewlish</a>. They had one daughter Nora Juanita Muriel Beckett, who married <a href="Eric%20Dillon%2C%2019th%20Viscount%20Dillon">Eric Dillon, 19th Viscount Dillon</a>. Beckett married for the second time in July 1915, at <a href="Westminster%20Cathedral">Westminster Cathedral</a> to Mary Philippa, of Culachy, <a href="Fort%20Augustus">Fort Augustus</a>, Scotland.
Army life.
In April 1869, Beckett purchased a commission as a <a href="cornet%20%28military%20rank%29">cornet</a> in the <a href="7th%20%28The%20Princess%20Royal%27s%29%20Dragoon%20Guards">7th (The Princess Royal's) Dragoon Guards</a>. Then two years later advances in rank to <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a> by purchase. His next position was as the regiments <a href="Adjutant">Adjutant</a>, which he held between May 1873 and October 1877. Then in February 1880, he exchanged position with a <a href="captain%20%28BARM%29">captain</a> from the <a href="3rd%20%28The%20King%27s%20Own%29%20Hussars">3rd (The King's Own) Hussars</a>, and joined that regiment as a captain. Two years later he saw his first combat action, when appointed as the <a href="Brigade%20Major">Brigade Major</a> for the Cavalry Brigade during the <a href="Sudan%20Campaign">Sudan Campaign</a>. This was followed by his promotion to <a href="major">major</a> in November 1884. In March 1886, he was appointed the Military Secretary to General His Serene Highness <a href="Prince%20Edward%20of%20Saxe-Weimar">Prince Edward of Saxe-Weimar</a>, commanding the Forces in Ireland. In May he was seconded for service with the General Staff. In August 1892, he was promoted to <a href="lieutenant-colonel">lieutenant-colonel</a> and given command of the <a href="2nd%20Dragoon%20Guards%20%28Queen%27s%20Bays%29">2nd Dragoon Guards (Queen's Bays)</a>. By May 1898 he was a <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="colonel">colonel</a> and was <a href="investiture">invested</a> as a Companion of the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Bath">Order of the Bath</a>.
Colonel.
In July 1898 he was appointed an assistant inspector-general of ordnance at headquarters, with the substantive rank of <a href="colonel">colonel</a>. He next served in the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a>, and was <a href="mentioned%20in%20dispatches">mentioned in dispatches</a>. and also became the Assistant-Adjutant-General in Natal in September 1899. He was then on the half pay list until July 1904, when he was appointed a Colonel on the Staff and the Chief Staff Officer for <a href="Malta">Malta</a>.
Brigadier-General.
His first appointment as a <a href="brigadier-general">brigadier-general</a> came in November 1905, while filling an administration post. On 21 July 1906 he was put onto the retired pay list, having completed his time on the administration staff. He then was given command of a brigade until 9 April 1912 he relinquished command, his tenure being up.
First World War.
At the start of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> Beckett, was appointed the Superintendent of the Remount Department. Although Beckett was now aged sixty-five, he was the first <a href="General%20Officer%20Commanding">General Officer Commanding</a>, the <a href="66th%20%282nd%20East%20Lancashire%29%20Division">66th (2nd East Lancashire) Division</a>. The division was created as the "2nd East Lancashire Division", a second-line mirror formation of the <a href="42nd%20%28East%20Lancashire%29%20Division">East Lancashire Division</a> at the end of August 1914. British <a href="Territorial%20Force%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Territorial Force</a> soldiers could not be deployed overseas without their consent, so the existing Territorial units were named as "first line" units, with men who had volunteered for overseas service, and a "second line", which was intended for home service only.
Charles Edward Beckett died on 17 September 1925, at his home in <a href="Fort%20Augustus">Fort Augustus</a>, Scotland.
